Key Arguments: Freedom of expression is vital in a democracy and should not be restricted by unelected bureaucrats.
During the Covid pandemic, platforms like Facebook and YouTube blocked messages that did not align with the official government stance, even from credentialed professionals.
Government or bureaucratic supervision of opinions on social media should be minimized.
Policies that impede or marginalize dissenting voices stifle debate and open discussion.
The Disinformation Bill 2023 sets a dangerous precedent by allowing bureaucrats to decide what is true or false.
Such laws are more characteristic of authoritarian regimes and do not belong in a free society like Australia.
Notable Quotes: Democracy can only work when citizens have genuine freedom of expression to dissimulate their views.
Giving a bureaucratic body like the ACMA to filter out what it regards as error, is the thin edge of the wedge.
A person would expect such a bill as the 'Disinformation Bill 2023' to be implemented by an authoritarian regime as found in Hong Kong.
